metadata.case_name: C.T. Senthilnathan Chettiar v. Agricultural Income-tax Officer

facts.text: The assessee, C.T. Senthilnathan Chettiar, executed a deed of settlement on November 19, 1959, in favour of Vatsala, his concubine.

The deed conferred a life interest only in the scheduled properties on Vatsala, without powers of alienation; after her lifetime, properties to children born to her by the settlor if alive, or revert to settlor or his heirs if no such children.
The deed reserved the settlor's right to cancel, revoke or alter the settlement if settlee fails to reside with settlor, misconducts, or other circumstances intervene.
Agricultural Income-tax Officer included income from settled lands in assessee's assessable agricultural income.

Assessee filed revision before Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, who held document evidenced revocable transfer, assets remaining property of settlor under section 9(1), refused exclusion of income.
Assessee filed revision under section 54(1) of the Act to Madras High Court, which agreed with Commissioner that settlement hit by section 9(1).
Assessee obtained special leave under Article 136 to appeal to Supreme Court; liberty given to urge additional grounds including ultra vires of section 9(1) and violation of Article 14.

legal_issues.text: Whether the settlement deed amounts to a revocable transfer of assets within section 9(1) of the Madras Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1955, making income from settled lands includible in assessee's income.
Whether section 9(1) of the Act is ultra vires the legislature and violative of Article 14 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Case governed by third proviso to section 9(1); income not assessable in assessee's hands until power of revocation exercised.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 9(1), third proviso, Madras Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1955

petitioner_arguments.text: Settlement creates life interest in Vatsala coupled with absolute interest in children; revocation accelerates vesting of absolute estate in children.
Section 9(1) ultra vires and violative of Article 14.

respondent_arguments.text: Settlement is revocable transfer, assets remaining property of settlor under section 9(1); income includible in assessee's hands.

court_reasoning.text: Settlement deed specifically reserves power to cancel, revoke or alter in circumstances, falling within first proviso to section 9(1) as settlor can reassume power over assets or income.
Section 126 of Transfer of Property Act not applicable to help assessee; assumes gift valid but revocable power retained.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If s.126 applies, gift void, but not concerned; focus on revocability.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot entertain challenge to validity of section 9(1) as tax authorities not concerned with ultra vires; point foreign to jurisdiction in revision/reference/appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Open to raise in appropriate proceeding.

holdings.text: Settlement deed amounts to revocable transfer within section 9(1); High Court right in holding income includible in assessee's agricultural income.
Question of section 9(1) being ultra vires cannot be raised before tax authorities, High Court or Supreme Court in this appeal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Validity of section 16(1)(c) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 left open.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balaji v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Akola
K.S. Venkataraman Co. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Tax authorities not concerned with validity of taxing provisions; ultra vires foreign to jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Straw Products Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed K.S. Venkataraman on jurisdiction over validity.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 9(1) deems income from revocable settlement as settlor's; revision under s.54(1).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar terms to section 9(1) of the Act.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Relied on by petitioner; court notes if applicable, gift void.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 for ultra vires challenge; Art.136 for appeal; Art.142 not enabling validity challenge.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court judgment upheld holding settlement hit by section 9(1), income from lands includible in assessee's assessable agricultural income; ultra vires challenge not entertainable.

key_quotes.text: the settlement deed specifically reserves power to the settlor to cancel or revoke or alter the settlement in any circumstances which require the cancellation or alteration of the deed of settlement.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Identifies revocability clause triggering section 9(1) proviso 1.

key_quotes.text: this clause falls squarely within proviso 1, for the assessee could at any time reassume power over the assets or the agricultural income by just cancelling or altering the terms of the deed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for upholding inclusion of income.

key_quotes.text: the authorities under a taxing statute are not concerned with the validity of the taxing provisions and the question of ultra vires is foreign to the scope of their jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bars constitutional challenge in tax proceedings.
